node.title: Why Are There So Many Premature Births in America?

node.title: Exonerations Only Deepen Mystery Shrouding Malcolm X’s Killing
node.description: Scholars have never accepted the official explanation for the murder. That is unlikely to change.

node.title: Giant Prehistoric Shark Teeth From 60-Foot Ocean Monster Unearthed in Desert
node.description: A single tooth from this fearsome megalodon predator is bigger than a man's hand.

node.title: Disallowed goals see Daniel Sturridge's A-League Men debut end in 1-1 draw
node.description: In front of a crowd of more than 17,000, the former Liverpool and England striker had 10 minutes at the end to try and snatch victory for the home side.

node.title: Chinese state media says Peng Shuai will appear 'soon', amid speculation over missing tennis star
node.description: Chinese state media employees post photos of missing sportswoman Peng Shuai, saying she is at home and "didn't want to be disturbed".

node.title: Mick Rock, Sought-After Rock Photographer, Dies at 72
node.description: His images of David Bowie, Lou Reed, Queen and others helped define the 1970s. He was still shooting the stars decades later.

node.title: Adding Surprise to Your Reading Life
node.description: Our critic recommends old and new books.

node.title: Ray Dalio Says ‘If You Worry, You Don’t Have to Worry’
node.description: The billionaire founder of the world’s largest hedge fund talked with DealBook about China, inflation and “The Changing World Order,” his new book about empires.

node.title: Internet Backs Mom After Mother-in-Law, Husband Veto Her Favorite Baby Name
node.description: The woman revealed her top choice was Raphael, and had considered Rafferty, so her son could still have the nickname Rafe or Raffi.

node.title: 10 Historical Questions That Can Get You Arrested in China
node.description: Telephone and online hotlines allow citizens to report others who talk about these 10 "rumours."

node.title: New Volcanoes Could Emerge Anywhere In US Southwest, Study Says
node.description: Volcanic fields pepper the southwestern U.S., posing a risk of new eruptions that could cause widespread devastation.

node.title: Austria braces for violence at mass protests over Covid measures.
node.description: The police in Vienna said that 10 of 11 demonstrations registered for Saturday involved protests over rules including a newly announced lockdown and vaccine requirement.

node.title: Dog Hailed a Hero After Surviving Bullet in Head Confronting Armed Intruder
node.description: Gus has been made an honorary police canine after being shot in the head by a convicted felon in his Tennessee backyard.

node.title: Diving save ensures goalless Sydney derby, Tony Popovic gets winning start as Victory boss
node.description: A long-range strike from Wanderers' former England international Jack Rodwell nearly sends the boisterous crowd of 23,118 into raptures during the tight derby.

node.title: U.S. Tries to Convince Arab Allies It Isn’t Abandoning Them
node.description: The defense secretary faced tough questions about how countries were supposed to deal with a U.S. national security policy that upends itself with each president.

node.title: Kyle Rittenhouse Lawyer Says 'There's Too Many Guns in Our Society'
node.description: Attorney Mark Richards told CNN's Chris Cuomo "I'm old enough when I remember you couldn't carry a gun."

node.title: Singapore will begin easing its Covid restrictions next week.
node.description: The Southeast Asian city state is recovering from a recent surge of hospitalizations. An official said its reopening would proceed in a “step-by-step manner.”

node.title: How to Get a Coronavirus Booster Shot in New York City
node.description: New Yorkers can get coronavirus vaccine booster shots at a number of places, including pop-up vans, churches, local pharmacies and community health clinics.

node.title: Inside Fentanyl’s Mounting Death Toll: ‘This Is Poison’
node.description: While a rise in overdose deaths shows the devastating consequences of the opioid’s spread, less is understood about how the drug has proliferated.

node.title: ‘When Are You Getting Married?’
node.description: The holiday season can sometimes lead to uncomfortable quizzing from meddlesome friends and family members about when you and your partner plan to wed. Here’s how to respond.

node.title: The Godmother of ‘Plant-Based’ Living
node.description: Frances Moore Lappé, the author of “Diet for a Small Planet,” which was published 50 years ago and spurred a movement toward vegetarianism, looks back on her legacy.

node.title: To Breed or Not to Breed?
node.description: In a world of pandemic chaos, political strife and climate catastrophe, some would-be parents see the future as too dark to procreate.

node.title: Career Coaching Today: Forget the Corporate Ladder and Find Yourself
node.description: The pandemic created a great reckoning among workers. Here to serve them is a raft of newfangled career coaches.

node.title: When Can the Covid Masks Finally Come Off?
node.description: Although the end of mask mandates is in sight, restrictions should remain in place through the holidays, experts say.

node.title: Family Unvisited, Travel a No-Go: The Hard Costs of High Gas Prices
node.description: They hit their highest level since 2014 last month, forcing Americans to rejigger household budgets and forgo leisure activities.

node.title: Allen Brooks, Victim of a 1910 Lynching, Is Remembered in Dallas
node.description: A historical marker will commemorate the intersection where a mob paraded Brooks’s body after he was savagely killed while awaiting trial.

node.title: One Historic Black Neighborhood’s Stake in the Infrastructure Bill
node.description: Generations of New Orleans residents have dreamed of the day when the Claiborne Expressway might be removed. President Biden’s $1.2 trillion infrastructure package could eventually make that possible.

node.title: Thousands rally against coronavirus restrictions in Australia.
node.description: Demonstrators gathered in cities around the country to protest vaccine mandates and other rules.

node.title: How Hunter Biden’s Firm Helped Secure Cobalt for the Chinese
node.description: The president’s son was part owner of a venture involved in the $3.8 billion purchase by a Chinese conglomerate of one of the world’s largest cobalt deposits. The metal is a key ingredient in batteries for electric vehicles.

node.title: Global Rivalries Are Miring the Clean Energy Revolution
node.description: The quest for Congo’s cobalt, which is vital for electric vehicles and the worldwide push against climate change, is caught in a cycle of exploitation, greed and gamesmanship.

node.title: Race to the Future: What to Know About the Frantic Quest for Cobalt
node.description: A New York Times investigation examines the global demand for raw materials as the clean energy revolution takes off. This is what we found.

node.title: Her Family and Pets Had Been Threatened, Said the Woman Who 'Ascertained' the Election

node.title: Kyle Rittenhouse Says He Wishes He Hadn't Gone to Kenosha 'a Hundred Times Over'
node.description: Mark Richards, the attorney for the acquitted teenager, told CNN his client regrets going to the city the night he fatally shot two people.

node.title: Heavy rain in India leaves 17 dead, dozens missing
node.description: The southern Indian state of Andhra Pradesh has been hit by intense torrents since Thursday, sparking massive floods in at least five districts, officials say.

node.title: Mega Millions Numbers for 11/19/21: Did Anyone Win the $74 Million?
node.description: A top cash prize option of $52.9 million was on offer on Friday but did anyone take home the big one?

node.title: North Melbourne's Ben Cunnington to undergo chemotherapy
node.description: Cunnington needs a nine-week course of chemotherapy, but the Kangaroos say he is expected to make a full recovery.

node.title: How Much Does Biden’s Spending Bill Actually Cost?
node.description: The climate change and social policy measure that the House just passed includes about $2.2 trillion worth of spending programs and tax cuts. But there are many ways to tally its price tag.

node.title: Mayor of Dutch city condemns protests that led to police firing shots at rioters
node.description: Crowds of rioters in the Dutch port city of Rotterdam torch cars and throw rocks at police after gathering to voice opposition to government plans to restrict access to indoor venues.

node.title: The flower giver: Spreading joy, one bunch at a time
node.description: A Tairua woman picked and delivered more than 300 bunches of flowers for people in her town in just two weeks with the sole purpose of spreading joy.

node.title: Flood-hit Canadian province limits petrol purchases, non-essential travel
node.description: British Columbia imposes restrictions on fuel and non-essential travel to ease supply chain disruptions and support recovery work after floods and mudslides that have destroyed roads, houses and left thousands stranded.

node.title: Cricket Australia admits it should have disclosed Paine investigation
node.description: Cricket Australia's current leadership team says the organisation made a mistake by not revealing in 2018 it was investigating Time Paine's role in a text-messaging incident with a woman, which has led to his resignation as men's Test captain.

node.title: Harmful ingredients lurking in vape products - study
node.description: The largest New Zealand study into vape products showed harmful bacteria, substances and chemicals are lurking in them.

node.title: Jury acquits US teen shooter Kyle Rittenhouse of all charges
node.description: A jury has acquitted Kyle Rittenhouse on charges that he murdered two men and attempted to kill a third during chaotic 2020 racial justice protests in Wisconsin.

node.title: Florida Veterans Group Gives Dog to 700th Service Member and First Vietnam Vet
node.description: "Coming to K9s For Warriors and receiving Loose has been the best experience of my life," the veteran said.

node.title: Twelve people to stand trial over Kardashian West jewel heist in Paris

node.title: Other legal fallout from the violence in Kenosha is still playing out in the courts.
node.description: Civil lawsuits accuse the authorities of wrongdoing, both during the turbulence in the city and in the police shooting that sparked it.

node.title: Kitten Up An Electricity Pole Rescued and Reunited With Worried Owner

node.title: Film Festival director departs after two seasons

node.title: Smaller crowds for anti-lockdown protests

node.title: Covid-19 update: 172 community cases in New Zealand today

node.title: Five deaths, more than 1100 cases as Victoria sees restrictions ease
node.description: There are 1166 new Covid-19 cases and five people have died as Victoria enters its its first weekend with new relaxed restrictions.

node.title: Cracks in building: 'If someone's under it they're going to be dead'

node.title: 'That route is closed': Unvaccinated travellers banned from entering Northern Territory
node.description: The Northern Territory will become the second jurisdiction in Australia to ban unvaccinated arrivals, with only limited exceptions, under sweeping changes to border rules announced by the Chief Minister.

node.description: Crowds of rioters in the Dutch port city of Rotterdam torch cars and throw rocks at police after several hundred people gathered to voice opposition to government plans to restrict access to indoor venues.

node.title: Photos from the sky show lush green paddocks turning into brown inland seas

node.title: Rittenhouse and the Right’s White Vigilante Heroes
node.description: The great threat is that there are young men out there who watched the verdict and now want to follow Rittenhouse’s lead.

node.title: Oklahoma Lawmaker Who Supports Death Penalty Laments Its Possible End in His State
node.description: Oklahoma has had a series of bungled legal injections, such as John Marion Grant's execution on Oct. 28. He was given Midazolam which caused him to convulse.

node.title: Senate Unanimously Confirms First Native American Leader of National Park Service

node.title: Investigation Into Former Gov. Cuomo Shows He Misrepresented Nursing Home COVID Deaths

node.title: Butterfield Will Not Run for a 10th Term in Congress; Blames Gerrymandering
node.description: "The map that was recently enacted by the legislature is a partisan map. It is racially gerrymandered," Butterfield said in the video announcing his retirement.

node.title: No two-legged intercontinental playoffs for last places at Qatar World Cup

node.description: The Chief Minister says the Northern Territory recorded one new case of coronavirus.

node.title: F.B.I. Agents Became C.I.A. Operatives in Secret Overseas Prisons

node.title: 1/6 Rioter Allegedly Brought Loaded Gun to Capitol, Filed False Report He Lost It at Casino
node.description: The man reportedly told his family that if authorities came to his house to arrest him, he would give himself up willingly "because I may go down as a hero."

node.title: Chicago School Staffers Removed for Alleged Inappropriate Relations with Students, Cover-Up

node.title: Political Fight After D.C. Mayor's Shift on Mask Mandate a Microcosm of Broader Battles
node.description: Residents of the capital will no longer need to wear masks in many indoor places on Monday, Nov. 22, but will still be required to do so at a few places.

node.title: Why did David feel like a million mosquitoes were biting his face?

node.title: Rare copy of US Constitution sells for $43.2m at auction

node.title: Biden fit for duty, polyp removed, says White House physician

node.title: 'The time is now': group disappointed by lack of changes to MIQ
node.description: A network of New Zealanders stuck overseas wants the MIQ system changed, when Auckland's borders are lifted on 15 December.

node.title: Rheumatic fever vaccine funding significant - Heart Foundation
node.description: The Heart Foundation says government funding for a possible rheumatic fever vaccine is an exciting step forward, which could benefit hundreds of people.
